docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 3 EVIDENCE EXCLUDED IN THE PUBLIC INTEREST [ss 129–131]

heading.title: DIVISION 3 EVIDENCE EXCLUDED IN THE PUBLIC INTEREST [ss 129–131]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 3 EVIDENCE EXCLUDED IN THE PUBLIC INTEREST [ss 129–131]

leg:heading.title: EVIDENCE EXCLUDED IN THE PUBLIC INTEREST [ss 129–131]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,155] s 129 Exclusion of evidence of reasons for judicial etc decisions

leg:heading.title: Exclusion of evidence of reasons for judicial etc decisions

p.text: Evidence of the reasons for a decision made by a person who is:
a judge in an Australian or overseas proceeding, or
an arbitrator in respect of a dispute that has been submitted to the person, or to the person and one or more other persons, for arbitration,

or the deliberations of a person so acting in relation to such a decision, must not be given by the person, or a person who was, in relation to the proceeding or arbitration, under the direction or control of that person.
Such evidence must not be given by tendering as evidence a document prepared by such a person.
This section does not prevent the admission or use, in a proceeding, of published reasons for a decision.

In a proceeding, evidence of the reasons for a decision made by a member of a jury in another Australian or overseas proceeding, or of the deliberations of a member of a jury in relation to such a decision, must not be given by any of the members of that jury.
This section does not apply in a proceeding that is:
a prosecution for one or more of the following offences:
an offence against or arising under section 319 , 321 , 322 or 333 of the Crimes Act 1900,
an offence against or arising under section 67 of the Jury Act 1977,
an offence connected with an offence mentioned in subparagraph (i) or (ii) , including an offence of conspiring to commit such an offence, or
in respect of a contempt of a court, or
by way of appeal from, or judicial review of, a judgment, decree, order or sentence of a court, or
by way of review of an arbitral award, or

a civil proceeding in respect of an act of a judicial officer or arbitrator that was, and that was known at the time by the judicial officer or arbitrator to be, outside the scope of the matters in relation to which the judicial officer or arbitrator had authority to act.
Subsection (5)(a) differs from section 129(5)(a) of the Commonwealth Act.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 873–875, 876
ALRC 38 paras 218–219
Legislation cited in [51,155.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 129(5), s 16.

The section complements the provisions of s 16 relating to the competence and compellability of judicial officers. Under that section, a judge in a proceeding is not competent to give evidence in that proceeding. Leave is required before a judge in former proceedings is compellable to give evidence in relation to them. Under the present section, unless s 129(5) applies, even a judge who is otherwise compellable cannot give evidence about the deliberations in the proceedings.

For the purposes of the section, the term “proceedings” means proceedings which are capable of producing a decision to which the section can apply. Accordingly, the procedure conducted by a Medical Assessor pursuant to the Motor Accidents Compensation Act which results in the issue of Certificates which are not binding upon the parties or the Court does not constitute “proceedings” to which the section applies: Ryan v Watkins [2005] NSWCA 426; BC200510431 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,160] s 130 Exclusion of evidence of matters of state

leg:heading.title: Exclusion of evidence of matters of state

p.text: If the public interest in admitting into evidence information or a document that relates to matters of state is outweighed by the public interest in preserving secrecy or confidentiality in relation to the information or document, the court may direct that the information or document not be adduced as evidence.
The court may give such a direction either on its own initiative or on the application of any person (whether or not the person is a party).
In deciding whether to give such a direction, the court may inform itself in any way it thinks fit.

Without limiting the circumstances in which information or a document may be taken for the purposes of subsection (1) to relate to matters of state, the information or document is taken for the purposes of that subsection to relate to matters of state if adducing it as evidence would:
prejudice the security, defence or international relations of Australia, or
damage relations between the Commonwealth and a State or between 2 or more States, or
prejudice the prevention, investigation or prosecution of an offence, or
prejudice the prevention or investigation of, or the conduct of proceedings for recovery of civil penalties brought with respect to, other contraventions of the law, or
disclose, or enable a person to ascertain, the existence or identity of a confidential source of information relating to the enforcement or administration of a law of the Commonwealth or a State, or
prejudice the proper functioning of the government of the Commonwealth or a State.
Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account for the purposes of subsection (1) , it is to take into account the following matters:
the importance of the information or the document in the proceeding,
if the proceeding is a criminal proceeding — whether the party seeking to adduce evidence of the information or document is a defendant or the prosecutor,
the nature of the offence, cause of action or defence to which the information or document relates, and the nature of the subject matter of the proceeding,
the likely effect of adducing evidence of the information or document, and the means available to limit its publication,
whether the substance of the information or document has already been published,

if the proceeding is a criminal proceeding and the party seeking to adduce evidence of the information or document is a defendant — whether the direction is to be made subject to the condition that the prosecution be stayed.
A reference in this section to a State includes a reference to a Territory.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 863–868
ALRC 38 paras 220–221
Legislation cited in [51,160.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 130(3).

The section is based on the common law concept of public interest immunity recognised in Sankey v Whitlam (1978) 142 CLR 1; 21 ALR 505; BC7800068 ; Conway v Rimmer [1968] AC 910; [1968] 1 All ER 874 . The section does not specify classes of documents which have an absolute immunity. All documents that relate to matters of state must be subjected to a balancing exercise, and reflects the common law position that no class of documents is completely immune from production: Public Transport Ticketing Corporation v Integrated Transit Solutions [2010] NSWSC 607; BC201003821 at [22] ; see also Haj-Ismail v Madigan (1982) 45 ALR 379 ; Hooker Corp v Darling Harbour Authority (1987) 14 ALD 110; BC8701389 per Rogers J. The term “public interest” is not defined. However, some of the factors which are relevant to an assessment of it are set out in s 130(5).

The section clearly applies to “information” (ie oral evidence) as well as documents and in this regard is consistent with the common law. Although s 130(3) provides that the court may inform itself as it thinks fit, the generally accepted practice is for the applicant to swear an affidavit setting out the nature of the information or documents that are sought to be protected. In those circumstances, there is authority for the proposition that the deponent of such an affidavit should not be cross-examined except in a rare case: Young v Quinn (1985) 4 FCR 483; 59 ALR 225. Even where cross-examination occurs, the court retains a residual discretion to disallow questions that are improper or not otherwise relevant to the proceedings: Re Buchanan (1964) WN (Pt 2) (NSW) 83; 65 SR (NSW) 9. See generally in relation to public interest immunity [23.3.28] where the matter is dealt with more fully.

The onus is on the party resisting disclosure to demonstrate that the document relates to matters of state and that the balancing test favours non production. This position is consistent with the position at common law (as to which see Cadbury Schweppes Pty Ltd v Amcor Ltd (2008) 246 ALR 137; (2008) ATPR ¶42-218; [2008] FCA 88; BC200800675 at [25]) and: see generally Public Transport Ticketing Corporation, above, at [20] and [49]; A3 v Australian Crime Commission [2006] FCA 894; BC20605542 ; Somerville v ASC (1995) 60 FCR 319 at 354; 131 ALR 517; 18 ACSR 236; BC9502845 .

The section imposes the onus on the party seeking to have the court exercise its discretion to prevent disclosure of a document, because it is the person seeking to prevent the production of a document that must demonstrate that the document relates to matters of state and that the balancing test favours non production. This position is consistent with the position at common law (as to which see Cadbury Schweppes Pty Ltd v Amcor Ltd (2008) 246 ALR 137; (2008) ATPR ¶42-218; [2008] FCA 88; BC200800675 at [25] ) andsee generally Public Transport Ticketing Corporation, above, at [20] and [49]; A3 v Australian Crime Commission [2006] FCA 894 .

The onus of proof has been described as a heavy burden, requiring the proponent of immunity who is resisting production to establish a real, as opposed to “some” or “any”, detriment to the public interest from disclosure of the document: Public Transport Ticketing Corporation, above, at [20], citing Somerville v ASC (1995) 60 FCR 319 at 354 .

The various matters to which reference is made in subs (4) are not exhaustive and are matters which, if the production of the document would cause one or more of them to occur, indicate that the document relates to matters of state: Public Transport Ticketing Corporation, above, at [21]. The principles underlying the section are necessarily subject to the broader requirements of the administration of justice: Commissioner of Police for NSW v Fandakis [2001] NSWSC 586; BC200103907 .
Legislation cited in [51,160.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 130(4)(a), s 183.

Where production of documents or disclosure of information is objected to on the grounds of national security ( s 130(4)(a) ) the court may inspect the documents to decide whether they ought be disclosed: Alister v R (1984) 154 CLR 404; 50 ALR 41; BC8300122 ; Commonwealth v Northern Land Council (1993) 176 CLR 604; 112 ALR 409; BC9303584 ; Mao v Commonwealth [2012] NSWSC 370; BC201202829 (Police Guidelines for Negotiation and Negotiation Incident Form — Balancing test — perusal by judge in unredacted form — dissemination would substantially weaken their utility and undermine the role of those who apply them); and see also s 183 of the Act. Examination is not appropriate in every case: Lanyon Pty Ltd v Commonwealth (1974) 129 CLR 650; 3 ALR 58; BC7400021 . As to the general principles relating to the desirability of the court inspecting documents to decide objections to their admissibility or production see [23.3.34] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,165] s 131 Exclusion of evidence of settlement negotiations

leg:heading.title: Exclusion of evidence of settlement negotiations

p.text: Evidence is not to be adduced of:
a communication that is made between persons in dispute, or between one or more persons in dispute and a third party, in connection with an attempt to negotiate a settlement of the dispute, or
a document (whether delivered or not) that has been prepared in connection with an attempt to negotiate a settlement of a dispute.
Subsection (1) does not apply if:

the persons in dispute consent to the evidence being adduced in the proceeding concerned or, if any of those persons has tendered the communication or document in evidence in another Australian or overseas proceeding, all the other persons so consent, or
the substance of the evidence has been disclosed with the express or implied consent of all the persons in dispute, or

the substance of the evidence has been partly disclosed with the express or implied consent of the persons in dispute, and full disclosure of the evidence is reasonably necessary to enable a proper understanding of the other evidence that has already been adduced, or
the communication or document included a statement to the effect that it was not to be treated as confidential, or
the evidence tends to contradict or to qualify evidence that has already been admitted about the course of an attempt to settle the dispute, or

the proceeding in which it is sought to adduce the evidence is a proceeding to enforce an agreement between the persons in dispute to settle the dispute, or a proceeding in which the making of such an agreement is in issue, or

evidence that has been adduced in the proceeding, or an inference from evidence that has been adduced in the proceeding, is likely to mislead the court unless evidence of the communication or document is adduced to contradict or to qualify that evidence, or
the communication or document is relevant to determining liability for costs, or
making the communication, or preparing the document, affects a right of a person, or
the communication was made, or the document was prepared, in furtherance of the commission of a fraud or an offence or the commission of an act that renders a person liable to a civil penalty, or

one of the persons in dispute, or an employee or agent of such a person, knew or ought reasonably to have known that the communication was made, or the document was prepared, in furtherance of a deliberate abuse of a power.
For the purposes of subsection (2)(j) , if commission of the fraud, offence or act is a fact in issue and there are reasonable grounds for finding that:
the fraud, offence or act was committed, and
a communication was made or document prepared in furtherance of the commission of the fraud, offence or act,
the court may find that the communication was so made or the document so prepared.
For the purposes of subsection (2)(k) , if:
the abuse of power is a fact in issue, and
there are reasonable grounds for finding that a communication was made or document prepared in furtherance of the abuse of power,
the court may find that the communication was so made or the document was so prepared.
In this section:
a reference to a dispute is a reference to a dispute of a kind in respect of which relief may be given in an Australian or overseas proceeding, and

a reference to an attempt to negotiate the settlement of a dispute does not include a reference to an attempt to negotiate the settlement of a criminal proceeding or an anticipated criminal proceeding, and
a reference to a communication made by a person in dispute includes a reference to a communication made by an employee or agent of such a person, and
a reference to the consent of a person in dispute includes a reference to the consent of an employee or agent of such a person, being an employee or agent who is authorised so to consent, and
a reference to commission of an act includes a reference to a failure to act.
In this section:
means a power conferred by or under an Australian law.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 890–894
ALRC 38 paras 222–223
Legislation cited in [51,165.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 30(4).

The provisions of s 131 are consistent with the common law relating to "without prejudice" communications. They apply to both oral and written communications: Seven Network Ltd v News Ltd (2006) 151 FCR 450; [2006] FCA 343; BC200601727 ; Noble Earth Technologies Pty Ltd v Hampic Pty Ltd t/as Cyndan Chemicals [2012] NSWSC 935; BC201206358 . The general principles relating to without prejudice communications are discussed in [21.5.135] and [21.5.140].

The party who claims that the evidence is excluded as a “without prejudice” communication bears the onus of establishing the factual basis of the claim: Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) v Rich [2004] NSWSC 1089; BC200407581 ; Liu v Fairfax Media Publications Pty Ltd (2012) 91 ACSR 158; [2012] NSWSC 900; BC201206959 . The mere fact that a communication is headed “without prejudice” is not conclusive of the question of whether or not it is privileged: GPI Leisure Corporation v Yuill (1997) 42 NSWLR 225; BC9704051 .

In determining whether documents fall within the protection of s 31(1) , the public policy behind the privilege is a relevant consideration. The section is designed to encourage full and frank settlement discussions between parties. It would conflict with that policy to confine narrowly the factual grounds that sufficiently establish the basis of the claim: Jireh International Pty Ltd t/as Gloria Jean’s Coffees v Western Export Services (Inc) No 2 [2011] NSWCA 294; BC201107168 ; Hong Kong Bank of Australia Ltd v Murphy (1992) 28 NSWLR 512; 8 ACSR 736; 10 ACLC 1573 ; Liu v Fairfax Media Publications Pty Ltd (2012) 91 ACSR 158; [2012] NSWSC 900; BC201206959 .

If material is caught by the prohibition in s 131(1) , and does not fall within one or more of the exceptions set out in s 31(2) , there is no general discretion to order that it may not be adduced: Moran v Moran (No 3) (2000) Aust Torts Reports 81-556; [2000] NSWSC 151; BC200001296 ; Liu v Fairfax Media Publications Pty Ltd (2012) 91 ACSR 158; [2012] NSWSC 900; BC201206959 .

The limited admissibility (in relation to liability for costs) provided for in s 131(2)(h) does not apply to communications during a formal mediation under the Civil Procedure Act 2005 . CPA s 30(4) completely prohibits the non-consensual admissibility of any such evidence: Azzi v Volvo Car Australia Pty Ltd (Costs) (2007) 71 NSWLR 140; [2007] NSWSC 375; BC200702783 ; Sharjade Pty Ltd v RAAF (Landings) Ex-Servicemen Charitable Fund Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1347; BC200811357 ; Mundine v Brown (No 7) [2011] NSWSC 170; BC201101510 .

level.toc-caption: [51,165.15] Exception to s 131(1) — Evidence likely to mislead — s 131(2)(g)

p.text: Legislation cited in [51,165.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 131(2)(g).

heading.title: Exception to s 131(1) — Evidence likely to mislead — s 131(2)(g)

p.text: The exception provided for in s 131(2)(g) only applies in relation to evidence that has been adduced in the proceedings. The exception cannot apply to require discovery of without prejudice communications merely on the basis of apprehensions about the likely scope of the evidence that may be given in the proceedings: Komatsu Marketing Support Australia Pty Ltd v Marsh Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 163; BC201201274 .

Differing views have been expressed, as between Judges of the Supreme Court of New South Wales and Judges of the Federal Court of Australia, regarding the breadth of s 131(2)(g) . The authorites are conveniently gathered in Barrett Property Group Pty Ltd v Dennis Family Homes Pty Ltd (No 2) (2011) 193 FCR 479; [2011] FCA 276; BC201101488 . It would seem that at the very least, in order to attract the operation of the section, something more than mere contradiction or qualification of earlier evidence is required: Brightstars Holding Co Pty Ltd v Johnston [2012] NSWSC 929; BC201206353 .

level.toc-caption: [51,165.20] Exception to s 131(1) — Evidence affecting a right of a person

p.text: Legislation cited in [51,165.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 131(2)(i).

heading.title: Exception to s 131(1) — Evidence affecting a right of a person

p.text: The exception provided for in s 131(2)(i) is directed to communications that, of themselves, have legal consequences for the rights of the parties: Ryder v Frohlich [2006] NSWSC 1324; BC200610119 ; Liu v Fairfax Media Publications Pty Ltd (2012) 91 ACSR 158; [2012] NSWSC 900; BC201206959 .
